image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: More than 3.6 million Queenslanders were enrolled to vote in the referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament — and with 68.5 per cent of ballots counted, just three of the state's 30 federal electorates supported the proposal.

title.children: You may not have heard of this electorate, but it just returned the strongest No vote in Australia

image.altText: An illustration showing two hexagons with the words No and Yes on them

items.synopsis: Scratch the surface of the Voice referendum results, and a more complicated picture emerges.

title.children: Beyond No, here’s what we know about the Voice results

image.altText: Headshot of a smiling Indigenous man in a patterned shirt

items.synopsis: While many say they are devastated by the No result in Saturday's referendum, First Nations leaders around the country are also hopeful that positive change can result.

title.children: Indigenous Australians look to the future with hope despite Voice  referendum defeat

image.altText: Two people look disappointed.

items.synopsis: Australia has rejected establishing a Voice to Parliament advisory body, with the majority of voters saying No to the proposed constitutional change. Follow what happens next with our live blog.

title.children: Australia rejects Voice to Parliament, with all six states voting No

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We take responsibility as the prime minister did last night, for the referendum and we take responsibility for the outcome," Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles said on ABC Insiders. "But I would say this. This referendum was the end step in a process which has been going on for a better part of a decade, in some respects longer. "I mean, it was the [John] Howard government which first talked about having recognition for Indigenous Australians in the constitution, and it was the [Tony] Abbott government who said that the way in which we should recognise Indigenous Australians is by asking Indigenous Australians how they want to be recognised in the constitution. "And that call really led to thousands of meetings which ultimately saw the meeting in 2017 at Uluru of Indigenous leaders which issued the Uluru Statement from the Heart and all we've done, in a sense is bring that to its final conclusion and taken that to the Australian people."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Richard Marles says government takes responsibility for referendum result

children.content: "We take responsibility as the prime minister did last night, for the referendum and we take responsibility for the outcome," Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles said on ABC Insiders.
"But I would say this. This referendum was the end step in a process which has been going on for a better part of a decade, in some respects longer.

"I mean, it was the [John] Howard government which first talked about having recognition for Indigenous Australians in the constitution, and it was the [Tony] Abbott government who said that the way in which we should recognise Indigenous Australians is by asking Indigenous Australians how they want to be recognised in the constitution.

"And that call really led to thousands of meetings which ultimately saw the meeting in 2017 at Uluru of Indigenous leaders which issued the Uluru Statement from the Heart and all we've done, in a sense is bring that to its final conclusion and taken that to the Australian people."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ABC Insiders is doing a Voice referendum special with Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles and Liberal Party MP Julian Leeser. You can watch the special in the stream below:

Richard Marles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: South Australian Liberal Party leader David Speirs says Prime Minister Anthony Albanese should resign, following the referendum result. "We saw David Cameron in the Brexit referendum, when the result didn't go the way he had endorsed he exited the stage. Perhaps Mr Albanese should do likewise."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: South Australia's Liberal Party leader says PM should resign

props.alt: A man stands in front of another man, both wearing a tie.

children.content: David Speirs has asked the PM to resign.
(ABC News)
South Australian Liberal Party leader David Speirs says Prime Minister Anthony Albanese should resign, following the referendum result.
"We saw David Cameron in the Brexit referendum, when the result didn't go the way he had endorsed he exited the stage. Perhaps Mr Albanese should do likewise."

image.altText: A map of Australia against a background of orange and purple stripes.

items.synopsis: Australia has voted No in the referendum, but the vote hasn't been uniform across states and cities. A small number of electorates, mainly in inner cities, are projected to have voted Yes.

title.children: A clear pattern has emerged in the way cities have voted in this referendum

image.altText: A worker cutting metal standing in front of an uncompleted steel structure.

items.synopsis: Sixteen young trade employees are dying at work a year in Australia, as safety concerns mount following the death of a teenage apprentice in Brisbane two weeks ago.

title.children: More than 150 young trade workers killed on sites in last decade, but those who speak out labelled 'weak-minded'

image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaks in front of the Australian, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags inside parliament house

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese vows to forge a new way forward to close the gap in life outcomes between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians, after voters resoundingly reject a Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'Not the end of the road': PM accepts referendum result, maps path forward for Indigenous recognition

image.altText: A huge crowd yells and holds up blue signs that say 'Vote no'.

items.synopsis: The federal government will be preparing for a difficult week of questions over what happens next, now that the Voice to Parliament has been rejected at a referendum.

title.children: Australians have rejected the Voice to Parliament. What happens now?

image.altText: a surfer with his surfboard on the floor votes at a polling centre in  bondi for the indigenous voice to parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Support for Yes was strongest in the inner suburbs, while the majority of outer suburban, regional and rural voters said No. But analysts say the reasons why voters rejected the referendum question is more complex.

title.children: Voice result reveals more than just Australia's country-city divide

image.altText: A woman wearing a backpack and carrying a baby walks through a crowd

items.synopsis: Israel's military says it's increasing operational readiness for the next stages of the war, with an emphasis on significant ground operations.

title.children: Israel prepares 'air, sea and land assaults' as Palestinians struggle to evacuate

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has visited soldiers on the front line outside Gaza, telling them the "next stage is coming". He toured two border villages, Kibbutz Be'eri and Kibbutz Kfar Aza, where the prime minister says "horrific massacres occured". In an accompanying video, he told soldiers: "You ready for the next stage? The next stage is coming." Since last Saturday's surprise attack, Israel has called up roughly 360,000 military reserves and gathered troops and tanks along the border with Gaza. No further details were given. You can continue reading the story below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Netanyahu tells soldiers 'next stage is coming'

featuredLink.title: Israel readies troops for invasion as Gaza residents flee their homes

Since last Saturday's surprise attack,
